facts.text: This is a Reference made by the President of India under Article 143(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: This is a Reference made by the President of India under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Object of Gujarat Act is to provide for regulation of transmission, supply and distribution of gas, in the interests of general public and to promote gas industry in the State, and to establish Gujarat Gas Regulatory Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the enactment is to provide for regulation of transmission, supply and distribution of gas, in the interests of general public and to promote gas industry in the State, and for that purpose, to establish Gujarat Gas Regulatory Authority and for matters companynected therewith and incidental thereto.

facts.text: Gas defined in Gujarat Act under Section 2(h) as matter in gaseous state which predominantly consists of methane.

anchor.surface_text: The term Gas has been defined in the Gujarat Act under Section 2 h  as follows- Gas means a matter in gaseous state which predominantly companysists of methane.

facts.text: Gujarat Act passed tracing legislative competence under Entry No. 25 of List II of Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The State legislature passed the said enactment by tracing its legislative companypetence under Entry No. 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution.

facts.text: Parliament passed enactments under Entry No. 53 of List I: Petroleum Act 1934, Oil Fields Regulation and Development Act 1948, Oil Industry Development Act 1974, Petroleum and Minerals Pipelines Act 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament has passed various enactments under Entry No. 53 of List I dealing with the matters of petroleum and petroleum products. ... The Federal Legislature passed Petroleum Act, 1934. The Union of India, inter alia, enacted various legislations, namely, The Oil Fields  Regulation and Development  Act, 1948 Oil Industry  Development  Act, 1974 The Petroleum and Minerals Pipelines  Acquisition of Right of User in Land  Act, 1962 the Oil Industry  Development  Act, 1974.

facts.text: Oil and Natural Gas Commission increased the price of natural gas supplied by them.

anchor.surface_text: Oil and Natural Gas Commission increased the price of natural gas supplied by them.

facts.text: Association of Natural Gas Consuming Industries of Gujarat and others filed Civil Writ Petition before High Court of Gujarat challenging legislative competence of Union to make laws on gas and gas works.

anchor.surface_text: The Association of Natural Gas Consuming Industries of Gujarat and others filed Civil Writ Petition before the High Court of Gujarat wherein they challenged the legislative companypetence of the Union to make laws on gas and gas works.

facts.text: Following three questions referred to Court under Article 143(1): 1. Whether natural gas including LNG is Union subject under Entry 53 List I. 2. Whether States have competence under Entry 25 List II. 3. Whether Gujarat had competence to enact Gujarat Act 2001.

anchor.surface_text: It is in this background, the following questions were referred to this Court under clause 1 of Article 143 of the Constitution of India Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I ... Whether the State of Gujarat had legislative companypetence to enact Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution  Act 2001.

facts.text: Notices served on States and Union Territories after receipt of Reference.

anchor.surface_text: After the receipt of the Reference, numberices were served on the States and the Union Territories.

facts.text: Learned Attorney General appeared for Union of India and contended natural gas is Union subject covered by Entry 53 List I as petroleum product.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney General for India appeared for the Union of India ... The learned Attorney General companytended that the various definitions in different encactments indicate that petroleum and petroleum product include natural gas and it was urged that natural gas is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I.

facts.text: Learned Counsel for State of Gujarat Shri Ashok Desai contended Entry 25 List II includes all types of gases including natural gas, cited Calcutta Gas Company case.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the State of Gujarat, Shri Ashok Desai companytended that the expression gas used in Entry 25 of List 11 would include all types of gases ... in Calcutta Gas Company  Proprietary  Ltd v. State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962  Suppl.  3 SCR I

facts.text: Plea of Gujarat adopted by almost all States.

anchor.surface_text: The plea made on behalf of the State of Gujarat was adopted by almost all the States.

facts.text: Court held natural gas including LNG is Union subject covered by Entry 53 List I, States have no competence under Entry 25 List II for natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative companypetence. ... Entry 25 of List II companyld only companyer manufactured gas and does number companyer Natural Gas within its ambit.

facts.text: Gujarat Gas Regulation Act 2001 ultra vires to extent relating to natural gas or LNG.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution  Act, 2001, so far as the provisions companytained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas  LNG  are companycerned, is without any legislative companypetence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

facts.text: Writ Petition and Civil Appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

facts.text: In Assam gas fields like Pingri, Thangakhat, Chubua, Jorajan, gases extracted not in association with any other substance.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that at a number of gas fields in Assam, operating in places like Pingri, Thangakhat, Chubua, Jorajan, gases were extracted number in association with any other substance and it is distinct from petroleum and oil.

facts.text: Natural gas defined in various Union legislations and rules as included in mineral oils or petroleum products.

anchor.surface_text: The Oil Fields  Regulation Development  Act, 1948 3 c Mineral Oils include natural gas and petroleum. Mines Act, 1952 2 jj  minerals ... includes mineral oils  which in turn include natural gas and petroleum

facts.text: Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd v. State of West Bengal held Entry 25 List II covers gas industry.

anchor.surface_text: in Calcutta Gas Company  Proprietary  Ltd v. State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962  Suppl.  3 SCR I, the scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II had been authoritatively pronounced by this Court

facts.text: Entry 25 List II relates to manufactured gas like for lighting, welding, not natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: Entry 25 under List II of the Seventh Schedule deals with gas and gas works and it relates to manufacture of synthetic gas. Initially manufactured gas was used for lighting street lamps
This is a Reference made by the President of India under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India.

issues.text: Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas LNG is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative competence to enact laws on natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: Whether natural gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact laws on natural gas.

issues.text: Whether States have legislative competence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and Liquefied Natural Gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Whether States have legislative competence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and Liquefied Natural Gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the State of Gujarat had legislative competence to enact Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution Act 2001.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the State of Gujarat had legislative competence to enact Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution  Act 2001.

issues.text: whether the State Government can pass an enactment in respect of gas, including natural gas in all its forms by virtue of the legislative competence based on Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: When the State of Gujarat passed the Gujarat Act, the question arose whether the State Government can pass an enactment in respect of gas, including natural gas in all its forms by virtue of the legislative companypetence based on Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule.

issues.text: whether Natural Gas is a Union subject or State subject and whether the State of Gujarat and the other States have the legislative competence to make laws on the subject of Natural Gas.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question arose whether Natural Gas is a Union subject or State subject and whether the State of Gujarat and the other States have the legislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of Natural Gas.

issues.text: whether the expression petroleum and petroleum products or mineral oil resources mentioned in Entry 53 of List I of the Seventh Schedule would take in its compass the natural gas or its derivative forms.

anchor.surface_text: The controversy in the instant case could only be resolved by examining the question whether the expression petroleum and petroleum products or mineral oil resources mentioned in Entry 53 of List I of the Seventh Schedule would take in its compass the natural gas or its derivative forms.

arguments.claim: Pith and substance doctrine: even incidental overlap ok, but no irreconcilable conflict

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of pith and substance is sometimes invoked to find out the nature and content of the legislation. However, when there is an irreconcilable conflict between the two legislations, the Central legislation shall prevail.

arguments.claim: Harmonious construction: reconcile Entries 53 List I and 25 List II; Entry 25 only manufactured gas

anchor.surface_text: If any entry overlaps or is in apparent conflict with another entry, every attempt shall be made to harmonise the same.

arguments.claim: Entry 25 List II: 'gas and gas works' means manufactured gas (e.g., for lighting, welding); not natural gas

anchor.surface_text: Entry 25 under List II of the Seventh Schedule deals with gas and gas works and it relates to manufacture of synthetic gas. Initially manufactured gas was used for lighting street lamps

arguments.claim: National interest: equitable distribution of natural gas requires Union regulation under Entry 53

anchor.surface_text: For free and smooth flow of trade, commerce and industry throughout the length and breadth of the country, natural gas and other petroleum products play a vital role... If one State alone is allowed to extract and use natural gas, then other States will be deprived of its equitable share.

arguments.claim: Gujarat Act ultra vires to extent it regulates natural gas/LNG

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas LNG are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Calcutta Gas distinguished: did not involve natural gas vs petroleum

anchor.surface_text: Though it is stated in the Calcutta Gas Companys case supra that under Entry 25 of List II the State Legislature has got powers to make any legislation regarding gas and gas-works, it cannot be of any assistance to support the constitutional validity of the Gujarat Act

holdings.text: Natural Gas including Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative competence to enact laws on natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative competence. ... Entry 25 of List II could only cover manufactured gas and does not cover Natural Gas within its ambit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history, statutory definitions including natural gas in petroleum/mineral oils, encyclopedic descriptions, and national interest in equitable distribution confirm coverage under Entry 53 List I.

holdings.text: The States have no legislative competence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Entry 25 under List II of the Seventh Schedule deals with gas and gas works and it relates to manufacture of synthetic gas. Initially manufactured gas was used for lighting street lamps

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 25 read as whole with 'gas and gas works' refers to manufactured/synthetic gas for lighting/welding etc., not natural gas; harmonious construction with Entry 53.

holdings.text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas (LNG) are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas LNG are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State lacks competence under Entry 25 for natural gas, which falls under Union's exclusive domain per Entry 53; Act trenches on Union field.

holdings.text: In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143(1) of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1 of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows directly from holdings on legislative competence resolving underlying challenges.

anchor.surface_text: ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ Petition and Civil Appeals dismissed. Reference answered: Natural gas (including LNG) is Union subject under Entry 53 List I with exclusive Union legislative competence; States have no competence under Entry 25 List II; Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply and Distribution Act, 2001 ultra vires to the extent relating to natural gas or LNG.

edges.explanation: The argument discussing scientific vs. statutory classifications of natural gas as petroleum addresses the issue of its inclusion in the constitutional entry

anchor.surface_text: Natural gas being a petroleum product, we are of the view that under Entry 53 List I, Union Govt. alone has got legislative competence. ... Entry 25 of List II could only cover manufactured gas and does not cover Natural Gas within its ambit.
ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.
Entry 25 under List II of the Seventh Schedule deals with gas and gas works and it relates to manufacture of synthetic gas. Initially manufactured gas was used for lighting street lamps

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas LNG are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.
